html.body:
In this step, we're going to have your $R{productServer} send out a broadcast signal across your local network. Any Device Servers connected to your network will then respond, thus allowing the server to figure out who's who.
  • Look at the System Tree (at the left side of the window)
  • Locate your $R{productServer} in this list.
  • Click the next to your $R{productServer} to expand its node.
  • Click the next to Device Servers node to expand it.
  • Locate the External Device Servers node:


  • Right-click it to show its context menu.
  • In the context menu, click Discover Device Servers:

Does your Device Server have a password? By default, Device Servers don't have passwords. If you've configured one for your Device Server, you should enter it here.
  • If you don't know whether or not you have a password, you probably don't. You can leave this field blank.
  • Now click on the Owner Name field.

The Owner Name is an important field. It lets you configure what User can see this Device Server.


Fill in the exact username of the user you wish to grant access to this Device Server. It is not case-sensitive, but if you make a typo, the user will not see the Device Server. So make sure you use the exact username for the account you created in the previous tutorial.


Once you've filled in the owner name, you can move to the next field.

Check Force connection even if Device Server is already configured for $R{productServer} or has incompatible firmware. This is a fairly self-explanatory option. You should check it as a safety precaution.

operation.title: External Device Servers / Connect Device Server to Server

html.body:
Establishing a manual connection: Can't see a Device Server?
If you see no Device Servers under External Device Servers, this means your server never got a reply when it sent out its broadcast. Possibly your Device Servers are unplugged, or some sort of a firewall configuration prevented the server from getting the reply. Another possibilty is that the Device Server is connected to a different network. In this case, you're going to have to establish a manual connection:
  • Right-click the External Device Servers node.
  • From the context menu, select Connect Device Server to server:
Wait while the dialog is shown...

showDescriptions.title: Wait for Device Server to Connect

html.body:
Now you have to allow for some time to pass, so that the Device Server could reboot and connect to the server.


This should take around 30 seconds. Take a deep breath and relax.Wait.


When 30 seconds have passed, click Next

Now that you've patiently waited, it is time to see if the Device Server is indeed connected and visible for the selected owner.

  • Locate the Users node in the system tree. Click to expand it.
  • Now locate the node for the User you've added the device for. Click to expand it.
  • Within this node, locate Device Servers (see screenshot below). Click to expand it.
  • You should now be able to see the Device Server you've added for this user. Its icon should be green, like this: .
  • All in all, your system tree should look something like this:



  • If this is what you see, well done! You can go ahead and click Next.

The tutorial will walk you through the process of connecting a Device Server to the server for a user.

It is written with the assumption that you are logged on as an Administrator who wishes to enable a User (the user account you have created in the previous tutorial) interact with a Device Server.

To begin, click Next.

You've now successfully completed the tutorial - well done!


The next step is to log out as an Administrator and log in as the User you've created before.


To do that, you're going to have to shut down the client. Click here to open the rest of this tutorial in a separate browser window.
